Shampoos often carry the claim that they are ''pH balanced,'' meaning that they contain a balance of acid and alkaline ingredients that matches that of hair. But this feature does not address the contradictory challenges of modern living, said Nasser N. Tehrani, a cosmetics chemist in Stamford, Conn. Bleaches and permanent waves can leave hair too alkaline, he said, while acid rain and air pollution can make it too acidic. As a result, he said, the proper pH level for a shampoo will vary with the circumstances.

To address this issue, Mr. Tehrani obtained a patent this week on what amounts to a litmus test for hair. The test employs a liquid containing two chemicals, bromthymol blue and methyl red, that change color in the presence of different pH levels. If drops of the liquid are applied to a fragment of hair and turn from green to yellow, the hair is more acidic than it should be, Mr. Tehrani said. If the drops turn blue, the hair is overly alkaline.
Mr. Tehrani, who said he was trying to license his invention, received patent 4,960,585.
